metadata.sermon_title: The Love Olympics Go to Jerusalem
metadata.sermon_start_end: Two weeks ago there was a very funny little article in The New York Times Styles section about the fact that this year, for the first time in decades, Valentine’s Day fell on the Saturday of a three-day holiday weekend. [...] The love Olympics have gone to Jerusalem. Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses two distinct passages (1 Cor 13 and Luke 9). While it attempts to link them, it fails Dekker's requirement of focusing on one specific pericope to find what is unique to it. Instead, it treats 'love' as a thematic bridge.
quotes: This same chapter on love was selected recently for a famous televised occasion
Listen again to St. Luke’s account of the story which is always read on this day
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either the Transfiguration or the Hymn to Love. By combining them, the specific 'strangeness' of the Transfiguration is flattened into a general illustration of 'mature love'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is thin. The preacher identifies Moses and Elijah as 'Law and Prophets' but does not delve into the Greek 'exodos' (departure) or the historical-theological necessity of the Jerusalem journey beyond a moral archetype of 'coming down'.
quotes: The appearance of Moses and Elijah ratifies the designation of Jesus as the Chosen One of Israel
the passage is really about the love of Christ as it takes shape in the Christian community
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Analyze the specific Greek context of 'agape' in 1 Cor 13 versus the 'exodos' in Luke 9. The sermon relies on cultural commentary (NYT, Vanity Fair) more than biblical-theological scholarship.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the sermon's strongest point. It uses concrete, contemporary examples (the taxi accident, the dying child, Martin Luther King Jr.) to ground the theological concept of 'descending love'.
quotes: Martin Luther King confronted furies ahead … [his] King’s inner course was fixed downward
the presence of her grandmother lying in bed beside her with her huge body embracing this precious, inhuman suffering
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid the 'generic idea of love' that the sermon itself critiques. Ensure the application remains tied to the specific text rather than becoming a series of moving anecdotes.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon moves back and forth between the biblical narrative and contemporary life. However, the 'exposition' often serves merely as a springboard for the 'application' rather than the two being mixed in a way that the text itself 'expounds' the hearer.
quotes: For you see, love cannot stay on the mountaintop. It must come down.
A few years back, I was crossing the street near my parish in New York City.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Let the text's own structure dictate the movement of the sermon rather than imposing a thematic 'downward' movement onto both texts.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is present (cancer, accidents, social injustice). Redemption is seen as Christ's descent into that misery. Gratitude (the third part) is less developed, appearing mostly as an invitation to discipleship.
quotes: he is about to become in his own person the embrace of God for all the misery of all the world.
Whenever you do this, you are becoming Jesus’ disciple.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' from physical suffering to the theological 'lostness' Dekker emphasizes. The sermon treats misery as 'pain' rather than 'sin' or 'alienation from God'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are almost entirely absent. There is no sense of the possibility of being lost or the gravity of the 'narrow way'. The tone is primarily comforting and inclusive rather than urgent or decisive.
quotes: And whoever you are and whatever your pain... he reaches out
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Introduce the 'seriousness of life design'. Contrast the 'broad way' of the 'love Olympics' (sentimentalism) with the 'narrow way' of the Cross as a life-or-death choice.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: The sermon is explicitly Christocentric. Christ is the telos. It correctly identifies that 1 Cor 13 is a description of Christ. It upholds the divinity and humanity (two natures) of Christ in his suffering.
quotes: The famous Corinthian chapter on love really describes Jesus.
God did not remain majestically aloof somewhere over the rainbow.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is not just a 'model of mature love' (moralism) but the actual Savior who accomplishes what man cannot.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 16 minutes, the sermon falls short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for true theological 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section to allow the text to speak more fully before moving into anecdotes.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its thematic approach, lack of length, and absence of the 'two ways'. It functions more as a thematic reflection on 'love' than a rigorous exposition of a single Bible passage. While the Christology is sound and the applications are concrete, it lacks the exegetical depth and the urgency of the call to decision that Dekker demands.
strengths: Concrete application through vivid, non-sentimental contemporary stories.
Clear Christocentric focus, identifying Christ as the fulfillment of the text.
Avoids 'general truths' by grounding the sermon in the specific movement of the liturgical year (Epiphany to Lent).
weaknesses: Insufficient length (under 20 minutes) limits theological depth.
Fails the 'one pericope' rule by merging two distinct texts.
Lack of the 'two ways' perspective; the sermon offers comfort without the tension of potential lostness.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a strong thematic speech with high-quality illustrations, but it is not a 'sermon' in the strict Dekkerian sense. It lacks the specific exegetical weight and the existential 'two ways' urgency required for the 'present of revelation'.
